answers.answer: Yes. There is nothing that says you need morning sickness (or any symptoms for that matter) and not having them doesn't mean the pregnancy is doomed. My mom never had nausea/vomiting with any of her 4 pregnancies.
am quite concerned because some say, the worse your preg symptoms, the healthier your baby would be.
Not true at all. Count your blessings, as you appear to be one of the lucky ones. ;-)Best wishes for a happy & comfortable 9 months.
Can someone tell me about glucophage & preganancy caz am on glucophage, my doc says i have to take it till am 5months

Hardly. Symptoms DO NOT mean a pregnancy is viable--in fact symptoms mean nothing at all. It's the reaction a female has to the pregnancy, nothing more. I've been pregnant twice, miscarried one. My first with my daughter I had nausea/vomiting, sore breasts and fatigue. My second I had BAD fatigue and nausea/vomiting--this is the one I lost. They 'claim' that nausea/vomiting indicates a strong pregnancy and this is untrue.I've seen many women with every symptom on the planet and lose it, while others with none go full term. Ignore it and enjoy your pregnancy. Many women would love to be symptom free--I know I would have given anything to not vomit everyday for 9 months.

glucophage is also known as metformin. It's used mostly in people who have diabetes, though women with PCOS also use it when attempting to conceive. I'm not sure why you would use it while pregnant unless you're diabetic.

am releaved. this is my 1st pregnancy and am 32yrs, beeen trying to conceive fro six years and it finally happened, so am quite nervouse abt anything out of the ordinary, so l would really appreciate any advice from all you sweet ladies
my insulin levels were very low, so the doc prescribed it as taking it increased my progesterone levels which were extreamly low, so after taking it for a year, i was able to conceive

question: am 8 weeks and still no morning sickness, is everything ok?
title: no morning sickness
